texts.definition: Goals that players have which at least some other players do not have knowledge about.
markups: <style="Definition">Goals that players have which at least some other players do not have knowledge about.</style>

Games gives players goals. However, some game give players <style="CurrentLink">Secret Goals</style> which other players are not aware of. This makes it more difficult for other players to disrupt those
goals but at the same time makes players want to find out what goals the other players have while continuing to keep their own goal secret.

<style="CurrentLink">Secret Goals</style> are most commonly used in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Games</link></style> and then to provide either victories if they are fulfilled or bonus points for determining winners. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlestar%20Galactica:%20The%20Board%20Game">Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dead%20of%20Winter:%20A%20Crossroads%20Game">Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game</link></style> are examples of the former in cooperative games and have the added twist that some players may be working against the other players. Examples of games where players can earn bonus points by reaching their <style="CurrentLink">Secret Goals</style> include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Amun-Re">Amun-Re</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Egizia">Egizia</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ticket%20to%20Ride">Ticket to Ride</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Lords%20of%20Waterdeep">Lords of Waterdeep</link></style>.

Players of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Roleplaying%20Games">Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Vampire:%20The%20Masquerade">Vampire: The Masquerade</link></style> often have characters with <style="CurrentLink">Secret Goals</style> and when players adopt these as part of roleplaying it becomes their own <style="CurrentLink">Secret Goals</style>. <style="CurrentLink">Secret Goals</style> can also appear in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Massively%20Multiplayer%20Online%20Games">Massively Multiplayer Online Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Eve%20Online">Eve Online</link></style> where players try to infiltrate each others' organizations.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style> are examples of classic games which have public goals. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Settlers%20of%20Catan">Settlers of Catan</link></style> have development cards that give bonus points, but these are fixed and do not provide goals so this is not an example of <style="CurrentLink">Secret Goals</style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Secret Goals</style> are typically introduced in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> to introduce <style="Link"><link="player-unpredictability">Player Unpredictability</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style>, and by doing so make it more difficult to perceive a <style="Link"><link="predictable-winner">Predictable Winner</link></style>. This in turn makes it less likely that players will try to <style="Link"><link="beat-leader">Beat the Leader</link></style> or begin <style="Link"><link="surrendering">Surrendering</link></style> due to feeling that they cannot win or have meaningful gameplay any longer. <style="CurrentLink">Secret Goals</style> can also be used to create or strengthen <style="Link"><link="internal-conflicts">Internal Conflicts</link></style> as well as make players become <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Traitors">Traitors</link></style>.

Designing <style="CurrentLink">Secret Goals</style> is not very different from designing other goals except of course that they require ways of keeping these secret. This may be done through <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> but in many cases <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> can work just as well (all the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Games</link></style> examples above do this). As a form of <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> can also handle <style="CurrentLink">Secret Goals</style> but more interestingly they can have their own <style="CurrentLink">Secret Goals</style>. A specific way of implementing <style="CurrentLink">Secret Goals</style> is through <style="Link"><link="secret-scoring-mechanisms">Secret Scoring Mechanisms</link></style>, which is basically the use of <style="CurrentLink">Secret Goals</style> to affect players' <style="Link"><link="scores">Scores</link></style> rather than simply providing them with victories. <style="Link"><link="player-defined-goals">Player Defined Goals</link></style> are in principle <style="CurrentLink">Secret Goals</style> until players tell others about them; when they are created for <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Roleplaying%20Games">Roleplaying Games</link></style> they are shared by <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style> and player and provide good basis for more challenging <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style>. That being said, having any <style="CurrentLink">Secret Goals</style> in a <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> encourages one to try and keep this secret which requires <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style>, so the pattern does give rise to <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> (or perhaps more accurately <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style>) even if there are no <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style> (the players are basically <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> a version of themselves that do not have the <style="CurrentLink">Secret Goals</style>). A prime example of this is any game where a player is planning to commit <style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style> in games can allow players more time to observe what other players are doing, and by this try to figure out what their <style="CurrentLink">Secret Goals</style> are.

<style="CurrentLink">Secret Goals</style> is not an <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Interface%20Patterns">Interface Pattern</link></style> but as mentioned above relies on a game interface which can provide secrets between players.

Secret Goals relate to gameplay goals and not the goals of narrative agents, so the pattern is not a Narration Pattern. However, Narration Structures can provide the basis for Secret Goals that relate to gameplay and can additionally make them easier to understand and remember due to being mirrored in the narration.

<style="CurrentLink">Secret Goals</style> introduces <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Imperfect%20Information">Imperfect Information</link></style> into any game and makes it difficult to perceive a <style="Link"><link="predictable-winner">Predictable Winner</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, thereby both adding <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> and making it difficult to <style="Link"><link="beat-leader">Beat the Leader</link></style> and consider <style="Link"><link="surrendering">Surrendering</link></style>.

The use of <style="CurrentLink">Secret Goals</style> tend to affect gameplay on a general level. Since it is beneficial for players to know what the other players' goals are, the pattern gives rise to <style="Link"><link="gain-information">Gain Information</link></style> goals and to counter this players may engage in <style="Link"><link="bluffing">Bluffing</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> to hide their true goals. This makes for more <style="Link"><link="player-unpredictability">Player Unpredictability</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style> in games that have <style="CurrentLink">Secret Goals</style>. The <style="Link"><link="gain-information">Gain Information</link></style> are likely to become even more valuable to succeed with if the <style="CurrentLink">Secret Goals</style> are also <style="Link"><link="committed-goals">Committed Goals</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-defined-goals">Player Defined Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="secret-scoring-mechanisms">Secret Scoring Mechanisms</link></style>
